title: Taking space safety cues from air and sea
summary:
Parallels with aviation and maritime industries offer important insights for managing increasingly congested orbits, according to a Feb. 6 panel of space technology executives at the SmallSat Symposium in Silicon Valley.
The post Taking space safety cues from air and sea appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: DIU studying applications of SpaceX Starship in-space refueling
summary:
A Defense Department unit is examining how SpaceX’s Starship vehicle could be used to support a broader architecture of in-space refueling.
The post DIU studying applications of SpaceX Starship in-space refueling appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: White House budget proposal could shatter the National Science Foundation
summary: "This kind of cut would kill American science and boost China."

title: NASA’s Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel Releases 2024 Annual Report
summary: The Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel (ASAP), an advisory committee that reports to NASA and Congress, issued its 2024 annual report Thursday examining the agency’s safety performance, accomplishments, and challenges during the past year. The report highlights 2024 activities and observations on NASA’s work, including: “Over the past year, NASA has continued to make meaningful progress […]

title: What You Need To Know About the March 2025 Total Lunar Eclipse
summary: The Moon will pass into Earth’s shadow and appear to turn red on the night of March 13 or early in the morning of March 14, depending on time zone. Here’s what you need to know about the total lunar eclipse. What is a lunar eclipse? A lunar eclipse occurs when the Sun, Earth, and Moon align […]

title: Geost sues Sierra Space over breach of contract in military satellite program
summary:
The sensor manufacturer alleges the satellite maker broke an agreement and misused Geost's status as a new market entrant to win a Space Development Agency contract before switching to a different supplier.
The post Geost sues Sierra Space over breach of contract in military satellite program appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: Robot Gets a Grip
summary: Blue tentacle-like arms attached to an Astrobee free-flying robot grab onto a “capture cube” in this image from Feb. 4, 2025. The experimental grippers demonstrated autonomous detection and capture techniques that may be used to remove space debris and service satellites in low Earth orbit. The Astrobee system was designed and built at NASA’s Ames […]

title: NASA CubeSat Finds New Radiation Belts After May 2024 Solar Storm
summary: Key Points The largest solar storm in two decades hit Earth in May 2024. For several days, wave after wave of high-energy charged particles from the Sun rocked the planet. Brilliant auroras engulfed the skies, and some GPS communications were temporarily disrupted. With the help of a serendipitously resurrected small NASA satellite, scientists have discovered […]

title: NASA’s Ethics Program
summary: NASA’s Ethics Program provides training and counsel to NASA employees and is responsible for the day-to-day management of the agency-wide ethics program. Headquarters and Center Chief Counsels ethics officials support the ethics program in their respective localities. A list of ethics officials at each NASA location can be found here: Headquarters and Center Ethics Officials. […]
